docs.lead_paragraph: Patients enrolled in profit-making health insurance plans are significantly less likely to receive the basics of good medical care -- including childhood immunizations, routine mammograms, pap smears, prenatal care, and lifesaving drugs after a heart attack -- than those in not-for-profit plans, says a new study that concludes that the free market is ''compromising the quality of care.'' The research, by a team from Harvard University and Public Citizen, an advocacy group in Washington, is the first comprehensive comparison of investor-owned and nonprofit plans. The authors found that on every one of 14 quality-of-care indicators, the for-profits scored worse. But because the researchers favored national health insurance, some questioned their findings.

headline.main: Report Says Profit-Making Health Plans Damage Care

docs.abstract: Study by team from Harvard University and Public Citizen advocacy group finds that patients enrolled in profit-making health insurance plans are significantly less likely to receive certain basic procedures; examples cited; Dr David U Himmelstein charges market is destroying health care system; study compared investor-owned and not-for-profit plans around country; findings detailed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Big Clashes in Teheran As Protests Intensify The police in Teheran fired tear gas at thousands of demonstrators and fired guns in the air as street battles raged. Iran's reformist President, Mohammad Khatami, who urged restraint and respect for the law on Monday, shifted his tone and condemned the protests. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield, a huge regional health insurer, announced yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to affiliate with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Maine. Anthem, based in Indianapolis, is a mutual insurer that has been steadily buying regional Blue Cross and Blue Shield companies across the United States. The size of the deal was not immediately disclosed.

headline.main: Two Blue Cross Plans Agree to Affiliate

docs.abstract: Anthem Blue Cross & Blue Shield agrees to affiliate with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Maine; financial terms undisclosed; Athem owns Blue Cross plans in Indiana, Connecticut, Kentucky and Ohio (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first tests of strength on managed-care legislation, Republicans in the Senate beat back Democratic amendments today on emotional issues like emergency room access and special medical protections for women. The Republicans also went on to pass measures of their own that in large part dismantled the Democrats' managed-care bill. The five votes on amendments to rival bills were a strong signal that the Republicans would stick together and pass their own bill at the end of a four-day debate over how to regulate health maintenance companies in the new era of managed care. Every vote ran largely along party lines, with three Republicans at most breaking with their party on any given issue.

headline.main: On Patients' Bill, Republicans Defeat Democrats' Provisions

docs.abstract: Senate Republicans beat back Democratic amendments to managed-care legislation, on emotional issues like emergency room access and special medical protections for women; party-line votes on amendments indicate Republicans will stick together and pass their own bill at end of four-day debate on regulating health maintenance companies; stalemate may be fought out in next year's elections; Pres Clinton appears with Democrats at White House to accuse Republicans of supporting toothless protections, under pressure from insurers; photo of Republican Sen Bill Frist during on-line discussion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Peter Edelman (Op-Ed, July 8) raises the question of what happens to families who leave the welfare rolls. Welfare reform has made poverty a private problem. While policy makers crow about the number of families leaving the welfare rolls, I see those same families showing up in increasing numbers at our child welfare agency in East Harlem.
docs.abstract: Letter from Ilze Earner, director of El Faro Beacon Youth and Family Services, shares Peter Edelman's concern about what happens to families who leave welfare rolls (July 8 Op-Ed)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since a health care revolution began moving patients into managed care more than a decade ago, the Senate opened a high-stakes debate today over how to protect their rights and regulate the companies that provide health insurance for most Americans. The legislation before the Senate is the Patients' Bill of Rights Act, the first of several politically potent health care issues to be debated by this Congress. It has broad implications for doctors, insurance companies, employers and individual consumers.

headline.main: Senate Takes Up Patients' Rights Bill

docs.abstract: US Senate begins high-stakes debate on Patients' Bill of Rights Act, aimed at protecting patients' rights and regulating companies that provide health insurance for most Americans; bill is among several politically potent health care issues to be debated by Congress, and has broad implications for doctors, insurance companies, employers and individual consumers; with health care issue of steady voter concern, struggle is deemed so significant for 2000 Congressional elections that Republicans and Democrats are going to unusual lengths to try to seize advantage in framing debate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Barrett Toan calls himself a silent partner in the health care system. And if President Clinton has his way, there will be many more like him. Mr. Toan is the president of Express Scripts Inc., which supervises the filling of 295 million prescriptions a year for 47 million people with private health insurance. In calling for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, Mr. Clinton wants to see Express Scripts and similar companies play the same role for 39 million older Americans and disabled people.

headline.main: Tracking Just What The Doctor Ordered; Medicare Changes Would Bolster Prescription Management Services

docs.abstract: Medicare changes proposed by Pres Clinton would bolster prescription management services; shift would illuminate some practices of management drug companies that have largely escaped public notice, including power of pharmacy benefit managers to affect doctors' decisions and their dealings with drug companies; arrangements, which include rebates from drug companies to managers for giving preference to certain drugs, would become much more visible; pharmacy benefit managers try to influence doctors' prescribing habits and encourage use of lower-cost drugs, including generic substitutes for brand-name medicines; in some ways, pharmacy benefit managers are like health maintenance organizations: they try to control cost of care; Barrett Toan, president of Express Scripts Inc, which supervises filling of 295 million prescriptions a year for 47 million people with private health insurance, comments on Clinton's program; list of top five prescription management companies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cost of Drink Recall Rises For Coca-Cola's Bottler Coca-Cola's bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, said that it would take a $103 million charge against second-quarter earnings to cover expenses associated with the recall of soft drinks in Europe last month, about 70 percent more than previously acknowledged. The charge erases second-quarter earnings for the bottler. Coca-Cola Enterprises said two weeks ago that the recall involved 14 million cases of soft drinks and would cost the company $60 million. But that number ballooned after 17 million cases of products were returned. [Page C7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Out in the fields, under an easy summer rain, a dozen men in blue slickers stooped over long rows of newly grafted cherry trees, staking each one so it stood straight. Dye from the wet stakes had turned Fernando Portugal's hands the green of an American dollar bill. Rain dripped from his plastic hood as he recalled how he had scraped together 300 American dollars, more money than he had ever seen, to pay a smuggler to help him enter the United States illegally in 1991.

headline.main: Niagara-on-the-Lake Journal; Low Pay and Hard Work, Blessed by Immigration

docs.abstract: Article on farm program run by Canadian Govt that allows thousands of migrant workers, mostly Mexican, into country each year for up to eight months; workers are paid $4.75 per hour, are provided with free housing and medical care and pension that will be sent to them when they retire; use of workers on farms in Niagara-on-the-Lake discussed; map; photo (M)
